results.title: From page to screen
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios, Morton Schindel, Paul R. Gagne and Ernest Troost
results.brief_description: This is the biography of a production company specialising in the adaption of children’s picture books onto the screen. Morton Schindel was a pioneer in his field when he set up in Weston Woods, Connecticut. His idea was to take the age old tradition of telling children stories and transfer it to film. In the 1950’s, when he began, picture books were not in schools as aids in teaching reading. “Dick and Jane” were relied on, but were not especially successful. Schindel consulted specialists and publishers in the children’s field to find books that met the criteria for adaption: Is the story meaningful to children? Do the illustrations reflect the text? Is the message universal? Will it stand the test of time? Initial choices, such as Ping and Mike Mulligan and his steam shovel, were produced, often with the help of the original illustrator. There was a strong response from children. They inspired children to look at the original book and were found to encourage reading. Children’s TV and schools were quick to take them up. Schindel named his company after the beautiful location of his studio and home, going on to produce many more high quality films of outstanding children’s books. This documentary tells the story and shows how the animations were done. Note: there are 126 Weston Woods titles in the Access Collection.

results.title: From Opera with Love
results.brief_description: This lively production dispels many widely held misconceptions about opera and shows that it can be as entertaining and exciting as a football match or a bullfight. Excerpts that are featured in this program are from, “the Pirates of Penzance”, “The Magic Flute”, “Carmen”, “Cosi fan tutte” and “The Barber of Seville”. Featuring Graham Blundell and Suzanne Johnston.

results.title: From one to many: Dvorak's 'Slavic Dance No. 7'
results.brief_description: Excerpt from Bruno Bozzetto’s “Allegro Non Troppo”. An animated comment on social confirmity set to the music of Dvorak. Featuring the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Herbert Von Karajan. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: From one cell
results.brief_description: This is a special-purpose film prepared for showing by biology teachers for class-room use. The subject of cancer is introduced objectively and unemotionally as one of the basic phenomenon of growth. The concept of cell growth and cell division is presented in terms which provoke interest in the as yet unanswered questions of abnormal cell behaviour.

results.title: From my point of view
results.creator_credit: John Friedman and Education Development Center
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Exploring Childhood”.
Uses sequences showing children from the ages of two and a half to five and a half with an adult in order to analyse the ways in which a child’s egocentrism affects the ability to see another person’s point of view. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: From Mao to Mozart: Isaac Stern in China
results.creator_credit: Harmony Film Group and Murray Lerner
results.brief_description: Isaac Stern and his family visited China for three weeks in 1989 as the guests of the Foreign Minister. Stern visits schools and conservatories of music, giving master classes and concerts, and speaking to music teachers who lived through the Cultural revolution.

results.title: From little things big things grow: Kev Carmody, singer (A)
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
Interspersed with video clips from his protest album “Pillars of society” Kev Carmody talks about his life and music. Born in Goronba, Queensland, on a cattle station, the son of an Irish stockman and his Aboriginal wife, Carmody spent his early years living off the land, but absorbing western culture through the ABC and old records. Taken away from his parents at the age of ten, he was put in a Christian school and sent home twice a year. After several years working at various menial jobs, whilst developing his music he eventually gained a Ph.D in Australian history, using oral material and methods rather than a written thesis. A fascinating portrait of a committed man.
